710072f-b.text:
Eighth Avenue, west side, north from 4. 14th to 15th Streets. Shown at the N. W. corner of 14th Street is the New York Savings Bank. View 3 is limited to this structure. No. 2 is photographed from atop the apartment house, No. 2 Horatio Street. It includes the New York Port Authority Building as a backdrop. On the right is the towering County Trust Building. This structure stands on the cleared site shown in the right foreground of View 1. Additional
construction shown is for a new subway.
View 1: May 30, 1929
View 2r March 16, 1933
View 3: February 14, 1932
P. L. Snerr

730225f-a.title: General view - [Manhattan - 14th Street - 8th Avenue (Northwest).]
730225f-a.text:
(1)
A general view, northwest from the County Trust Co., Building, at the N.E. corner of 14th Street, and Eighth Ave., showing the Hudson River in the background, and the London TTerrace Apartments in the centre background, (23rd St from Ninth to Tenth Aves).
May 31, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, a year later.
June 18, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

711304f-a.text:
14th Street, West from between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, showing south side, from the roof of the new County Trust Building at Eighth Ave and 14th street. St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church is in the left foreground.
May 31 1930

711299f-b.text:
(1) 14th Street, east from Eighth Avenue, view from the twenty-two story Lawyer's Trust Company Building, favoring the south side.
On the south side, at 214-16 West 14th Street, west of Seventh Avenue, stands the newer Daggett & Randall Building, erected around 1918, eight stories tall. Then comes a rear view of the newly completed twenty-story apartment house on Seventh Avenue adjoining the S.W. corner of 14th Street, the twelve-story loft building on the S.E corner, erected a little prior to 1920, and the brand new Salvation Army Building aat 120 West 14th Street. On the S.E. corner of Eighth Avenue is Carson's 14th Street Store, built there after R. H. Macy & Company moved up to 34th Street.
June 16, 1931.
P. L. Sperr

(2) A portion of the same and showing the back yards between West 14th abd 15th Streets as seen from the same point of view.
June 16, 1931.
P. L. Sperr

711299f-a.text:

Then comes a rear view of the newly completed twenty-story apartment house on Seventh Avenue adjoining the S.W. corner of 14th Street, the twelve-story loft building on the S.E corner, erected a little prior to 1920, and the brand new Salvation Army Building aat 120 West 14th Street. On the S.E. corner of Eighth Avenue is Carson's 14th Street Store, built there after R. H. Macy & Company moved up to 34th Street.
June 16, 1931.
P. L. Sperr

(2) A portion of the same and showing the back yards between West 14th abd 15th Streets as seen from the same point of view.
June 16, 1931.
P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, at the S. W. corner of 7. 14th Street (right) showing the former New York County National Bank building. THis institution was absorbed by the Manufacturesf Trust Company. Note
in View 2 the changed title across the facade.
View 1: March 21, 1931
View 2: February 14, 1932
P. L. 5perr

730229f-a.title: General view - [Manhattan - 14th Street - 8th Avenue (Southeast).]
730229f-a.text:
A general view, southeast from 14th Street, at the northeast corner
of Eighth Ave.
September 2, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

711298f-a.text:
309-11 (Old No. 187-89 West 14th Street north side, west of Eighth Avenue, a double house probably built around 1850; it is on the maps as early as 1852. 14th Street has always been numbered east and west from Fifth Avenue, but originally it was not the custom to start with a fresh hundred at each numbered avenue.
July 16, 1932
P.L. Sperr

711305f-a.text:
325-27 West 14th Street, north side, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, twin brownstones probably built not long after the Civil War.
July 16, 1932.
P.L. Sperr

710075f-a.text:
Eighth Avenue, west side, north from 14th Street, showing construction work on Port Authority Building.
February 14, 1932.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

710073f-b.text:
Eighth Avenue, south from W. 14th Street, as photographed from atop the Port Authority Building at No. 111 Eighth Avenue. The triangular park shown is Jackson Square. This is one block to the south of 14th Street and is bounded by 8th Avenue, Greenwich Avenue and Horatio Street. The tall apartment building there is at the S. W. corner of the last two thoroughfares and is identified as No. 2
Horatio Street.
April 26, 1933
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr

710073f-a.text:
Eighth Avenue, south from W. 14th Street, as photographed from atop the Port Authority Building at No. 111 Eighth Avenue. The triangular park shown is Jackson Square. 710079f-b.text:
Eighth Avenue, east side, from Greenwich Avenue, to W. 14th Street, as photgraphed from aton the apartment house, No. 2 Horatio Street. Greenwich Avuenue is the diagonal thoroughfare in the foreground and upon which is the white ventilator building (8th Avenue Subwav) and the parking lot. 14th Street runs across the top, with its County Trust Company Building at the N. E. corner.
March 16, 1933
Views 1,2
P . L. Sperr

710079f-a.text:
Eighth Avenue, east side, from Greenwich Avenue, to W. 14th Street, as photgraphed from aton the apartment house, No. 2 Horatio Street. 711296f-a.text:
General View from Penthouse at 56 Seventh Avenue, Manhattan

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer

Neg. No. 254
(Note: negative at Museum of the City of New York)
Code 1 D
July 14, 1937
711296f-a.folder: 14th Street (West) & Between 7th and 8th Avenues., Manhattan, NY

710074f-b.text:
(1)
Eighth Ave., south from West 14th to Hudson Streets and showing on the left,the western side of a small triangular park; Jackson Square. The buildings seen across same are Nos. 18 to 14 Horatio Street.
April 17, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A complete view of the block shown on therdght of No. 1. These structures are Nos. 65 to 79; the latter being the New York County National Bank at the S.W. corner of West 14th Street. In the foreground of this photo appears the only entrance to the park which is
on Greenwich Ave.
April 17, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A view slightly southward of No. 1; this being from West 13th Street (left). Photographers vantage point is on Eighth Ave. at
Greenwich Ave.
April 17, 1937.

711300f-a.text:
310-312 (old Nos. 198-200) West 14th Street, south side, west of Eighth Avenue, the western two houses of a group of five, probably all alike, of the 1850 period. 14th Street has always been numbered east and west from Fifth Avenue, but it was not always the custom to start with a fresh hundred at every numbered avenue.
The older Dagget and Handdall Building (six stories), at 314 adjoining, replaced an old residence some time between 1902 and 1910. The occasion of making this photograph was probably the purchase of those two houses, with 306-308 adjoining, by the interests that demolished them and then erected a double six-story apartment house n the site
About 1912

711302f-a.text:
14th Street, sourth side, from Eighth Avenue to Hudson Street and
Ninth Avenue, inclusive, showing the New York County National
Bank in its marble building, 77-9 Eighth Avenue on the S.W. corner
of 14th Street, erected around 1906 on the site of its older
location, 79 Eighth Avenue. By 1934 this building will be occupied
by a branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company.
Adjoining the bank is 306-12 West 14th Street, a double apartment
house built around 1913 or 1914 (see 310-12 West 14th Street, about 1912), and beyond it what used to be the Daggett & Ramsdell Building,
314 West 14th Street. In the middle of the block stands St.
Bernard's Roman Catholic Church (1873-5).
On the eastern side of Eighth Avenue, 14th Street is partially boarded
over, as work is in progress on the extension (opened 1932) of the
B. M. T. 14th Street subway.
May 31, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

711303f-a.text:
14th Street, north side, from Eighth to Ninth Avenues (northern end
of Hudson Street).
February 14, 1932.
P.L. Sperr
